adjective.description: Used to single out an individual member of a specified group or class.
examples: the action seems to discriminate against a particular group of companies
when handling or checking cash the cashier should exercise particular care

adjective.description: Insisting that something should be correct or suitable in every detail; fastidious.
examples: she is very particular about cleanliness

noun.description: An individual item, as contrasted with a universal quality.

examples: he is wrong in every particular

phrases: he socialized with the other young people, one boy in particular
The first half in particular was epitomised by a real uncertainty in dealing with crosses.
One of Maurice, in particular, bought tears to her eyes as the memories flooded back.
Toddlers in particular are not known for the patience and sitting still skills.
Part of it had to do with the players themselves, and in particular the contrast between them.
origin: Late Middle English: from Old French particuler, from Latin particularis concerning a small part, from particula small part.
